title: Charles Bukowski, William Burroughs, and the Computer (2009)
summary:
Charles Bukowski, William Burroughs, and the Computer (2009)

Charles Bukowski's relationship with technology, particularly the Macintosh computer, was transformative in his later years. Despite initial skepticism, Bukowski embraced the computer as a tool for creativity and productivity. He experimented with fonts, formatting, and the ease of deleting and editing text, which influenced the style and structure of his poetry. The computer also served as a metaphor for the aging writer and the end of the traditional author, as well as the potential for new forms of expression and preservation in the digital age.
